title: How can an attorney sue me for a debt that is 13 years old?
question: I recently was notified via writ of execution from the sheriffs office in regards to a judgement. I was never even notified of a court date nor did i have any clue someone was suing me. It turns out its my landlord from 13 years ago trying to collect now for move out discrenpencies. The previous landlord is also an attorney himself. I thought California has a 4 year statue of limitations on debt collecting? What can I do since he got a judgement? How did the courts even allow for him to obtain a judgement on a 13 year old debt? I'm so confused. I was researching online and it said it's illegal for him to sue someone with a debt this old especially he is an attorney he should now better. I would really appreciate some help thank you so much.
answers:
I agree with the other answers. Most likely you were sued many years ago and served by substitute service (e.g. publication in a newspaper) and the judgment was entered. Bottom line is there is obviously a judgment against you, so you can either (1) seek to set aside the judgment in state court if you have a legal basis to do so (such as improper service of the summons/complaint). That is an expensive way to go and may not be a high likelihood of winning; (2) settle with them and make payment arrangements or (3) file a bankruptcy case to deal with this and any other debts you might have.

I suggest you have a consultation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your State to learn about your eligibility and options.

More information is needed to give you useful advice. Perhaps, the judgment was obtained within 4 years of the date you last paid, but the service of the lawsuit was flawed or non-existent. Judgments are enforceable for 10 years, plus additional 10 year periods when an application to renew is timely filed. BK may be the most efficient manner to solve this problem. Remember, BK is more than checking boxes on forms you find online. Find/consult/hire a lawyer in your area using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it.

Because the bankruptcy process can be handled entirely by phone, email and fax, there is no need to personally visit the lawyer’s office unless you want to. Don’t be limited by the location of the BK lawyers you select.

Do you have a copy of the judgment? Chances are it was entered years ago, and you weren't served properly which is why you didn't know you were being sued. This happens quite a bit.

You might be able to get copies of the papers in the case via the court's online register of actions. You want copies of the complaint, the proof of service of summons, the request for entry of default and the judgment.

With those papers you can engage an attorney experienced in vacating old judgments. Don't be discouraged by lawyers who tell you it is too late. That only means they have never done it.
